pairs.stoic_text:
The reader will, in some measure, be able to judge by this taste what
he is farther to expect; that is to say, as to the cast of my design,
and the simplicity of the style and dress; for that will still be the
same, only accompanied with variety of matter. Whether it pleases the
world or no, the care is taken; and yet I could wish that it might be
as delightful to others upon the perusal, as it has been to me in the
speculation. Next to the gospel itself, I do look upon it as the most
sovereign remedy against the miseries of human nature: and I have ever
found it so, in all the injuries and distresses of an unfortunate life.
You may read more of him, if you please, in the _Appendix_, which I
have here subjoined to this Preface, concerning the authority of his
_writings_, and the circumstances of his _life_; as I have extracted
them out of Lipsius.
pairs.neutral_text: Based on this sample, readers can judge what to expect from the rest of the book. The style and approach will remain the same, though the topics will vary. I don't know if others will like it, but I've done my part. I hope readers will enjoy it as much as I have enjoyed thinking about these ideas. After the Bible, I consider this the best cure for human suffering, and it has helped me through many difficulties in my unlucky life. If you want to learn more about the author, you can read the Appendix I've added to this Preface. It contains information about his writings and life story, which I took from Lipsius.

pairs.stoic_text:
Some few fragments, however, of those books of his that are wanting,
are yet preserved in the writings of other eminent authors, sufficient
to show the world how great a treasure they have lost by the excellency
of that little that is left.
pairs.neutral_text: However, small pieces of his missing books can still be found in the writings of other well-known authors. These fragments are good enough to show people what a valuable collection of work was lost, based on the high quality of the small amount that remains.

pairs.stoic_text:
Seneca, says Lactantius, that was the sharpest of all the Stoics,
how great a veneration has he for the Almighty! as for instance,
discoursing of a violent death; “Do you not understand?” says he, “the
majesty and the authority of your Judge; he is the supreme Governor of
heaven and earth, and the God of all your gods; and it is upon him that
all those powers depend which we worship for deities.” Moreover, in his
Exhortations, “This God,” says he, “when he laid the foundations of the
universe, and entered upon the greatest and the best work in nature, in
the ordering of the government of the world, though he was himself All
in all, yet he substituted other subordinate ministers, as the servants
of his commands.” And how many other things does this Heathen speak of
God like one of us!
pairs.neutral_text:
According to Lactantius, Seneca was the most intelligent of all the Stoic philosophers and showed great respect for God. For example, when discussing violent death, Seneca said: "Don't you understand the power and authority of your Judge? He is the highest ruler of heaven and earth, and the God above all your gods. All the powers that we worship as deities depend on him."

In his written advice, Seneca also said: "When this God created the universe and began the most important and best work in nature - organizing how the world would be governed - even though he was everything and everywhere, he still appointed other lesser officials to carry out his orders."

This non-Christian philosopher said many other things about God that sound like what Christians believe.

pairs.stoic_text:
Which the acute Seneca, says Lactantius again, saw in his Exhortations.
“We,” says he, “have our dependence elsewhere, and should look up to
that power, to which we are indebted for all that we can pretend to
that is good.”
pairs.neutral_text: According to Lactantius, the philosopher Seneca made a perceptive observation in his written advice. Seneca said that people should rely on and respect a higher power, since this power is the source of anything good that people possess or claim to have.

pairs.stoic_text:
And again, Seneca says very well in his Morals, “They worship the
images of the God,” says he, “kneel to them, and adore them, they are
hardly ever from them, either plying them with offerings or sacrifices,
and yet, after all this reverence to the image, they have no regard at
all to the workman that made it.”
pairs.neutral_text: Seneca makes a good point in his writings about ethics. He observes that people pray to statues of gods, bow down to them, and worship them. They stay close to these statues most of the time, bringing gifts and making sacrifices to them. However, despite showing all this respect to the statues themselves, they completely ignore the craftsmen who actually created them.

pairs.stoic_text:
Lactantius again. “An invective,” says Seneca in his Exhortations, “is
the masterpiece of most of our philosophers; and if they fall upon
the subject of _avarice_, _lust_, _ambition_, they lash out into such
excess of bitterness, as if railing were a mark of their profession.
They make me think of gallipots in an apothecary’s shop, that have
remedies without and poison within.”
pairs.neutral_text: Lactantius mentions this point again. In his Exhortations, Seneca said that most philosophers are best at writing harsh criticisms. When they write about greed, sexual desire, or the pursuit of power, they become extremely bitter in their attacks, as if harsh criticism is their main job. This reminds me of medicine jars in a pharmacy - they appear to contain cures on the outside, but actually hold poison inside.

Lactantius continued: "Anyone who wants to understand everything should read Seneca. He describes public vices and behaviors more vividly than anyone else, and he criticizes them more effectively than anyone else."

pairs.stoic_text:
And again; as Seneca has it in the books of Moral Philosophy, “He is
the brave man, whose splendor and authority is the least part of his
greatness, that can look death in the face without trouble or surprise;
who, if his body were to be broken upon the wheel, or melted lead to be
poured down his throat, would be less concerned for the pain itself,
than for the dignity of bearing it.”
pairs.neutral_text: According to Seneca's writings on ethics, a truly courageous person is one whose fame and power are not their most important qualities. This person can face death calmly without being upset or shocked. Even if they were tortured by being broken on a wheel or having molten lead poured down their throat, they would worry more about maintaining their dignity during the suffering than about the physical pain itself.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is truly and excellently spoken of Seneca, says Lactantius, once
again; “Consider,” says he “the majesty, the goodness, and the
venerable mercies of the Almighty; a friend that is always at hand.
What delight can it be to him the slaughter of innocent creatures or
the worship of bloody sacrifices? Let us purge our minds, and lead
virtuous and honest lives. His pleasure lies not in the magnificence of
temples made with stone, but in the pity and devotion of consecrated
hearts.”
pairs.neutral_text: Lactantius quotes Seneca again, saying that Seneca made an excellent point. Seneca said people should think about God's power, kindness, and mercy, since God is always available to help. He argued that God does not enjoy the killing of innocent animals or blood sacrifices. Instead, Seneca believed people should improve their thinking and live moral lives. He said God cares more about compassionate and devoted hearts than about expensive stone temples.

pairs.stoic_text:
“Here follows now,” says Tacitus, “the death of Seneca, to Nero’s great
satisfaction; not so much for any pregnant proof against him that he
was of Piso’s conspiracy; but Nero was resolved to do that by the sword
which he could not effect by poison. For it is reported, that Nero
had corrupted Cleonicus (a freeman of Seneca’s) to give his master
poison, which did not succeed. Whether that the servant had discovered
it to his master, or that Seneca, by his own caution and jealousy, had
avoided it; for he lived only upon a simple diet, as the fruits of the
earth, and his drink was most commonly river water.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here is the same passage rewritten in plain language:

Tacitus reports that Seneca died next, which greatly pleased Nero. This wasn't because there was strong evidence that Seneca had joined Piso's conspiracy against Nero. Rather, Nero had decided to kill Seneca with a sword since poisoning him had failed. According to reports, Nero had bribed Cleonicus, one of Seneca's freed slaves, to poison his master, but the plan didn't work. This failure happened either because the servant warned Seneca about the plot, or because Seneca was naturally suspicious and careful about what he consumed. Seneca ate only simple foods like fruits and vegetables, and usually drank only water from rivers.

pairs.stoic_text:
This is not to discountenance the veneration we owe to parents; nor
to make children the worse, but the better; and to stir up generous
emulations: for, in contests of good offices, both parties are happy;
as well the vanquished as those that overcome. It is the only honorable
dispute that can arise betwixt a father and son, which of the two
shall have the better of the other in the point of benefits.
pairs.neutral_text: This doesn't mean we should stop respecting our parents or make children behave worse - actually, it should make them behave better by encouraging healthy competition. When people compete to do good things for each other, everyone wins, including the person who doesn't do as much. The only worthwhile competition between a father and son is trying to see who can do more good things for the other person.

pairs.stoic_text:
When Domitius was besieged in Corfinium, and the place brought to great
extremity, he pressed his servant so earnestly to poison him, that at
last he was prevailed upon to give him a potion; which, it seems, was
an innocent opiate, and Domitius outlived it: Cæsar took the town, and
gave Domitius his life, but it was his servant that gave it him first.
pairs.neutral_text: When Domitius was trapped in the city of Corfinium during a siege and the situation became desperate, he repeatedly asked his servant to poison him. Eventually, the servant agreed and gave him a drink. However, the drink was actually just a harmless sleeping potion, not poison, so Domitius survived. Later, Caesar captured the city and spared Domitius's life, but technically it was the servant who had already saved him first by giving him fake poison.

pairs.stoic_text:
There was another town besieged, and when it was upon the last pinch,
two servants made their escape, and went over to the enemy: upon the
Romans entering the town, and in the heat of the soldiers’ fury, these
two fellows ran directly home, took their mistress out of her house,
and drove her before them, telling every body how barbarously she had
used them formerly, and that they would now have their revenge; when
they had her without the gates, they kept her close till the danger was
over; by which means they gave their mistress her life, and she gave
them their freedom. This was not the action of a servile mind, to do so
glorious a thing, under an appearance of so great a villainy; for if
they had not passed for deserters and parricides, they could not have
gained their end.
pairs.neutral_text: During a siege, when a town was about to fall, two slaves escaped and joined the attacking Roman army. When the Romans entered the town and began killing people, the two men ran to their owner's house. They grabbed their mistress and forced her to come with them, loudly telling everyone that she had treated them badly and they wanted revenge. They took her outside the town gates and kept her there until the violence ended. This saved her life, and afterward she freed them from slavery. Their actions were actually noble, even though they had to appear villainous to succeed. If they hadn't pretended to be traitors seeking revenge, they wouldn't have been able to save her.

pairs.stoic_text:
In the civil wars of Rome, a party coming to search for a person of
quality that was proscribed, a servant put on his master’s clothes,
and delivered himself up to the soldiers as the master of the house;
he was taken into custody, and put to death, without discovering the
mistake. What could be more glorious, than for a servant to die for his
master, in that age, when there were not many servants that would not
betray their masters? So generous a tenderness in a public cruelty;
so invincible a faith in a general corruption; what could be more
glorious, I say, than so exalted a virtue, as rather to choose death
for the reward of his fidelity, than the greatest advantages he might
otherwise have had for the violation of it?
pairs.neutral_text:
During the Roman civil wars, soldiers came looking for a nobleman who had been marked for execution. The man's servant put on his master's clothes and pretended to be the master. The soldiers arrested him and killed him without realizing their mistake.

This was an impressive act. During that time period, most servants would have betrayed their masters. Despite the widespread violence and general dishonesty of the era, this servant remained completely loyal. His virtue was exceptional - he chose to die rather than betray his master, even though he could have gained significant benefits by turning his master in instead.

pairs.stoic_text:
THERE MUST BE JUDGMENT IN A BENEFIT, AS WELL AS MATTER AND INTENTION;
AND ESPECIALLY IN THE CHOICE OF THE PERSON.
pairs.neutral_text: When giving help or benefits to others, you need to use good judgment. This applies to three things: what you give, why you give it, and most importantly, who you choose to give it to.

pairs.stoic_text:
As it is the _will_ that designs the benefit, and the _matter_ that
conveys it, so it is the _judgment_ that perfects it; which depends
upon so many critical niceties, that the least error, either in the
person, the matter, the manner, the quality, the quantity, the time, or
the place, spoils all.
pairs.neutral_text: When giving a benefit to someone, three elements are involved: the will (your intention to help), the matter (the actual thing or help you provide), and the judgment (how you decide to give it). The judgment is what makes the benefit truly effective, but it requires careful attention to many specific details. If you make even a small mistake in any of these areas—choosing the wrong person, giving the wrong thing, using the wrong approach, misjudging the appropriate type or amount, picking the wrong time, or choosing the wrong location—the entire benefit will fail.

pairs.stoic_text:
Next to the choice of the _person_ follows that of the _matter_;
wherein a regard must be had to time, place, proportion, quality;
and to the very nicks of opportunity and humor. One man values his
peace above his honor, another his honor above his safety; and not
a few there are that (provided they may save their bodies) never
care what becomes of their souls. So that good offices depend much
upon construction. Some take themselves to be obliged, when they are
not; others will not believe it, when they are; and some again take
obligations and injuries, the one for the other.
pairs.neutral_text: After choosing the person, you must choose the subject matter. You need to consider timing, location, scale, and quality, as well as the right moments and moods. Different people have different priorities: some value peace more than honor, others value honor more than safety, and some only care about physical survival and ignore moral concerns. Therefore, helpful actions depend largely on how they are interpreted. Some people feel obligated when they actually aren't, others refuse to acknowledge real obligations, and some people confuse obligations with harmful actions.

pairs.stoic_text:
The particularity does much, but yet the same thing may receive
a different estimate from several persons; for there are ways of
marking and recommending it in such a manner, that if the same _good
office_ be done to twenty people, every one of them shall reckon
himself peculiarly obliged as a cunning whore, if she has a thousand
sweethearts, will persuade every one of them she loves him best. But
this is rather the artifice of conversation than the virtue of it.
pairs.neutral_text: Individual circumstances matter a lot, but different people may judge the same action differently. There are ways to present and promote an action so that if you do the same favor for twenty people, each one will feel specially indebted to you - similar to how a manipulative person with many romantic partners will convince each one that they are the most loved. However, this is more about clever social manipulation than genuine virtue.

pairs.stoic_text:
There is not any benefit so glorious in itself, but it may yet be
exceedingly sweetened and improved by the _manner_ of conferring it.
The virtue, I know, rests in the _intent,_ the profit in the judicious
application of the _matter_; but the beauty and ornament of an
obligation lies in the _manner_ of it; and it is then perfect when the
dignity of the office is accompanied with all the charms and delicacies
of humanity, good-nature, and address; and with dispatch too; for he
that puts a man off from time to time, was never right at heart.
pairs.neutral_text: No benefit is so valuable that it cannot be made much better by how it is given. The moral worth comes from the giver's intention, and the usefulness comes from applying the gift wisely. However, what makes a favor attractive depends on how it is delivered. A favor is complete when the important act of giving is combined with kindness, good nature, and proper social skills - and it should be done quickly. Someone who keeps delaying and putting off giving help was never genuinely willing to help.

pairs.stoic_text:
Suppose a man makes suit for a place, and cannot obtain it, but upon
the ransom of ten slaves out of the galleys. If there be ten, and
_no more_, they owe him nothing for their redemption; but _they_ are
indebted to him for the choice, where he might have taken ten others
as well as these. Put the case again, that by an act of grace so many
prisoners are to be released, their names to be drawn by lot, and mine
happens to come out among the rest: one part of my obligation is to him
that put me in a capacity of freedom, and the other is to Providence
for my being one of that number. The greatest benefits of all have no
witnesses, but lie concealed in the conscience.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

Consider a man who applies for a job but can only get it if he pays to free ten slaves from prison ships. If there are exactly ten slaves available, they don't owe him anything for freeing them since he had to free them anyway to get the job. However, they do owe him gratitude for choosing them, since he could have picked any ten slaves.

Now imagine a different situation: the government decides to release a certain number of prisoners by drawing names randomly from a hat, and my name gets selected. In this case, I owe thanks to two parties - first to the person who made it possible for me to be freed, and second to luck or fate for having my name chosen. The most important acts of kindness often happen without anyone else knowing about them, existing only in a person's private thoughts and feelings.

pairs.stoic_text:
There is a great difference betwixt a common obligation and a
particular; he that lends my country money, obliges me only as a part
of the whole. Plato crossed the river, and the ferry-man would take no
money of him: he reflected upon it as honor done to himself; and told
him, “That Plato was in debt.” But Plato, when he found it to be no
more than he did for others, recalled his words, “For,” says he, “Plato
will owe nothing in particular for a benefit in common; what I owe with
others, I will pay with others.”
pairs.neutral_text:
There is a big difference between a general obligation and a personal one. When someone lends money to my country, they only create an obligation for me as part of the group, not as an individual.

Here's an example: Plato was crossing a river, and the ferry operator refused to accept payment from him. Plato initially thought this was a special honor given to him personally, so he said "Plato is now in your debt." However, when Plato discovered that the ferry operator gave free rides to everyone, he changed his position. He said "Plato owes nothing special for a common benefit. If I owe this debt along with everyone else, then I'll pay it back along with everyone else."

pairs.stoic_text:
This is one of those subtleties, which, though hardly worth a man’s
while, yet it is not labor absolutely lost neither. There is more of
trick and artifice in it than solidity; and yet there is matter of
diversion too; enough perhaps to pass away a winter’s evening, and keep
a man waking that is heavy-headed.
pairs.neutral_text: This is one of those minor points that isn't very important, but it's not completely worthless either. It relies more on clever techniques than substantial content, but it can still be entertaining. It might be enough to fill an evening and help someone stay alert when they feel drowsy.

pairs.stoic_text:
But without any further alteration of dialogue, the conclusion is this;
if you meant him the kindness, he is answerable for it, and I may enjoy
the fruit of it without being obliged by it: but if it was done for
my sake, then I am accountable; or howsoever, upon any occasion, I am
ready to do you all the kind offices imaginable; not as the return of
a benefit, but as the earnest of a friendship; which you are not to
challenge neither, but to entertain as an act of honor and of justice,
rather than of gratitude. If a man find the body of my dead father in
a desert, and give it a burial; if he did it as to my father, I am
beholden to him: but if the body was unknown to him, and that he would
have done the same thing for any other body, I am no farther concerned
in it than as a piece of public humanity.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

To conclude this discussion: if you did the favor for his benefit, then he owes you for it, and I can benefit from it without owing you anything. But if you did it for my benefit, then I owe you. Either way, I'm willing to do favors for you whenever possible - not to pay back a debt, but as a sign of friendship. You shouldn't demand this from me, but should accept it as something I do because it's right and fair, not because I'm grateful.

For example: if someone finds my dead father's body in a desert and buries it, whether I owe them depends on their reason. If they buried it specifically because it was my father, then I owe them. But if they didn't know whose body it was and would have buried any body they found, then I don't owe them anything - they were just doing a basic human duty.

pairs.stoic_text:
Nay, Providence itself is gracious to the wicked posterity of an
honorable race. The counsels of heaven are guided by wisdom, mercy, and
justice. Some men are made kings of their proper virtues, without any
respect to their predecessors: others for their ancestors’ sakes, whose
virtues, though neglected in their lives, come to be afterward rewarded
in their issues. And it is but equity, that our gratitude should extend
as far as the influence of their heroical actions and examples.
pairs.neutral_text: No, Providence actually treats the unworthy descendants of good families kindly. Heaven's decisions are based on wisdom, mercy, and justice. Some people become kings because of their own good qualities, regardless of who their ancestors were. Others become kings because of their ancestors' virtues, which may not have been properly recognized when those ancestors were alive, but are later rewarded through their descendants. It is fair that our gratitude should reach as far as the lasting effects of their heroic actions and examples.

pairs.stoic_text:
THERE ARE MANY CASES WHEREIN A MAN MAY BE MINDED OF A BENEFIT, BUT IT
IS VERY RARELY TO BE CHALLENGED, AND NEVER TO BE UPBRAIDED.
pairs.neutral_text: There are many situations where someone can be reminded of a favor they received, but it should very rarely be demanded back, and it should never be used to criticize or blame them.

pairs.stoic_text:
If the world were wise, and as honest as it should be, there would be
no need of caution or precept how to behave ourselves in our several
stations and duties; for both the giver and the receiver would do what
they ought to do on their own accord: the one would be bountiful, and
the other grateful, and the only way of minding a man of one good turn
would be the following of it with another. But as the case stands, we
must take other measures, and consult the best we can, the common ease
and relief of mankind.
pairs.neutral_text: If everyone were wise and honest, we wouldn't need rules about how to act properly in different roles and responsibilities. Both people who give and people who receive would naturally do the right thing: givers would be generous, and receivers would be thankful. The only way to remind someone of a favor would be to do them another favor. However, since this isn't how things actually work, we need to use different approaches and try our best to figure out what will help and benefit people in general.

pairs.stoic_text:
Assiduity of obligation strikes upon the conscience as well as the
memory, and pursues an ungrateful man till he becomes grateful: if one
good office will not do it, try a second, and then a third. No man can
be so thankless, but either shame, occasion, or example, will, at some
time or other, prevail upon him. The very beasts themselves, even lions
and tigers, are gained by good usage: beside, that one obligation does
naturally draw on another; and a man would not willingly leave his own
work imperfect. “I have helped him thus far, and I will even go through
with it now.” So that, over and above the delight and the virtue of
obliging, one good turn is a shouting-horn to another. This, of all
hints, is perhaps the most effectual, as well as the most generous.
pairs.neutral_text: Consistently helping someone affects both their conscience and memory, and keeps pressuring an ungrateful person until they become grateful. If one favor doesn't work, try a second one, then a third. No one is so ungrateful that shame, circumstances, or seeing others' examples won't eventually influence them. Even wild animals like lions and tigers can be won over through kind treatment. Additionally, one favor naturally leads to another, and people don't like to leave their work unfinished. They think, "I've helped this person so far, so I might as well continue." Therefore, beyond the satisfaction and moral value of helping others, one good deed encourages another. This approach is probably both the most effective and the most generous of all strategies.

pairs.stoic_text:
The counsels of a wise man are certain, but events are uncertain: and
yet if I have passed a rash promise, I will in some degree punish the
temerity of making it with the damage of keeping it, unless it turn
very much to my shame or detriment, and then I will be my own confessor
in the point, and rather be once guilty of denying, than always of
giving. It is not with a benefit as with a debt—it is one thing to
trust an ill paymaster, and another thing to oblige an unworthy
person—the one is an ill man, and the other only an ill husband.
pairs.neutral_text:
A wise person's advice is reliable, but outcomes are unpredictable. If I make a hasty promise, I will generally follow through with it as a way to learn from my mistake, unless doing so would seriously harm my reputation or well-being. In those cases, I will admit my error to myself and choose to break the promise once rather than repeatedly give unwisely.

Giving help is different from lending money. There's a difference between trusting someone who doesn't pay back loans and helping someone who doesn't deserve it. The first person is dishonest, while the second is simply bad at managing resources.

pairs.stoic_text:
Should Philip now have kept this promise? First, he owed the soldier
nothing. Secondly, it would have been injurious and impious; and,
lastly, a precedent of dangerous consequence to human society; for it
would have been little less than an interdiction of fire and water to
the miserable, to have inflicted such a penalty upon relieving them; so
that there must be always some tacit exception or reserve: _if I can_,
_if I may_; or, _if matters continue as they were_.
pairs.neutral_text: Should Philip have kept his promise? There were three reasons why he shouldn't have. First, he didn't owe the soldier anything. Second, keeping the promise would have been harmful and wrong. Third, it would have set a bad example for society. If Philip had punished someone for helping people in need, it would have been almost like forbidding anyone from giving basic assistance to those who are suffering. Therefore, promises should always include unspoken conditions like "if I'm able to," "if it's appropriate," or "if the situation stays the same."
